ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The course provided just what I needed - an opportunity to practise and be critiqued on my communication skills. It pinpointed areas for improvement. It tried to cover a lot in quite a short space of time and more opportunities for practising would be useful - but we can access that through the FES comms people at any time, so this course was great for just making me aware of my own strengths and weaknesses. It was great to learn alongside my peers and be able to give and receive criticism as a class.
The course was very useful and helped improve my communication skills.

This was too much work for a 1 credit class. VERY valuable information/feedback, though. I believe that everyone at FES should be required to take this class during their first semester.Would be helpful if there were a way to incorporate this into our full semester of classes rather than having us do weekly assignments. For example, we would be required to put the concepts into practice in our other classes as part of the Communications class. Instead of having to make up short presentations/speeches/panels, have us be evaluated on how we perform during our regular course load.
This course should be expanded into a 3 credit course. I found it exceptionally valuable and I think everyone should take it.
N/A
This is an excellent course-- almost feel like it should be mandatory for all FES students!
The course is very valuable, but I can't say it's a great deal of fun.
This course is incredibly useful to students hoping to gain experience in public speaking, it really should be "required" (though it's better that it's not) it's just that useful!

Ironically, the instructions for some of the assignments were unclear and many people were confused as to what exactly was expected for the assignment. I suggest Vance make the instructions as clear and explicit as possible.
Opportunity to practise and hone communication skills, sharing the process with my peers.
the ability to practice presenting in front of communication experts.
The concise, take-away messages William delivered during the lectures.
Clear, utilitarian rules/best practices, concise readings, and useful homework.
Hands on practice with communication skills, including valuable feedback.
The weekly practicing of public speaking skills.
Practical skills; useful for professional experience
William creates very good exercises to force you out of your comfort zone and become a better public speaker. His presentations are also very good.
The emphasis on self reflection after seeing your own video-recorded presentations was very helpful. There was a lot of built in support that felt individualized.
The best part was how interactive it was. Everyone had the opportunity to practice during every single class.
The quality of teaching- William Vance was prepared every week and he is knowledgeable in this field.
1.The break out sessions.2. The access to the communication coaches.
The opportunity to be recorded giving presentations and to get feedback.
Great Communication Coaches, especially Julie Vance! She gave very thorough and helpful feedback and recommended strategies to improve that were ultimately very useful.
Every FES student needs to take this course, it was very well done
Forcing us to practice communications skills, however awkward it felt.
Practicing the skills we were learning was helpful, and it was also helpful to learn about where we could find additional resources within FES (e.g. the communications coaches).
Professor, TA, materials, the professor's assistants, especially Julie Vance
Assignments forced students to practice the communication skills, which was helpful in actually learning them.

The course really helped me gain confidence in communication skills. It provided the most comfortable setting to practice speech, presentation, debate, etc. skills because all other students were in the class for the same reason, and I did not have to be afraid of making mistakes.
The best thing about this course is that it is very helpful to improve your communication skills.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I don't think it's in much need of improvement
So much information in such short a time frame.
Better small group practice sessions; I felt they were always running late, and students were always under prepared.
Would be nice to get individualized feedback from the professor and/or TAs on our weekly assignments. He only offers aggregated feedback for the entire class.
How short it is -- have it be 3 units!
More relevant readings and more resources to use
The Monday 6-8 pm time slot is a little rough. Can the school get us some snacks or something?
None
I would like to see this course as a Full semester. But overall, I think it is well taught for a 6 week session.
The instructors are smart and well-meaning, but strangely socially awkward and hard to get to know. Not a terrible barrier, but it is awfully discordant for a class on communications skills.
It might have been helpful to get more tips about one-on-one communication and communication in meetings, as most of the content was focused more formal presentation formats.
The course could have been for longer duration and slower.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructors were all very helpful and offered really useful criticism. Sometimes a bit intimidating in their strict professionalism but for the greater long-term good!
Instructor, TA, and Communication coaches were all excellent.
Good
Very good - very responsive to email.
Great - always available
William, the TA, and all the coaches are very responsive to emails and giving feedback on your work. William reviews all your assignments and gives you feedback on all of them.
The course instructor and other co-facilitators offered specific advice to all the students in the class in terms of how each of us could improve our communication skills.
Margo was very accomodating. William was also accessible.
Excellent. Margo was always available and helpful.
It was helpful to have a team of communications experts to work with, everyone had a different style. William and Margo were both very helpful.
Great!
Communication coaches have been available out of class. Instructor was reachable via email.
very available
Excellent, both by email for questions during the course of the class and for ongoing personalized help.
Superior--both TA and professor
Very responsive.
It was great to get immediate feedback from the communication skills coaches/TA/instructor during the practices.
The quality of work was commendable.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It doesn't really relate to my academic work but will be very useful for presenting myself professionally.
This class was simply the most helpful class during my time at FES. Good communication is essential to anything and everything I will be doing in the future.

As a professional rather than an academic, I found this course to be essential. Most FES students do not have the communication skills William Vance teaches in this course, and if FES is a professional school, it should do a better job at teaching these skills.
Improved significantly my communication skills

I was previously terrified of public speaking and also felt pretty lost when standing in front of a group of people but this course helped a lot. It gave me some confidence as well as some valuable take home lessons on public speaking, presentations, meeting organization, etc.

Communications is applicable to all FES students, no matter what specialized area one wishes to go into. I feel like this course covered a broad range of topics (from email writing to formal presentations) and is useful for anyone going into a field where they will have to communicate effectively with others.
It doesn't fit directly but communication is an important school that all should have.
This professional training in communication was one of the most valuable courses that I took while at FES.
This course provided a tangible skill set that I can apply to any environmental work that I do.
Very well.
This course should really be advised for students to take in the Fall of their first year. It's essential training that comes in handy in every course at FES.
i need to know how to communicate effectively ,and this course TRULY lived up to it's claims
These skills are very useful for summer internships, post-grad school work life, as well as presentations within my classes at FES.
Just useful life skill, professional presentations
Everyone can benefit from these skills, especially since many people in my program need to communicate scientific material, this is helpful in teaching methods to do this effectively.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To improve my comms skills
To become a better public speaker.
To improve my communication skills.
I wanted to work on my communication skills, which is not covered in other classes here at FES.
Very important skills to master for the workforce.
To improve my communication skills.
To practice and learn more about communication
I needed to work on my public speaking skills.
I took this course because I wanted to perfect my public speaking skills.
I wanted to improve my public speaking skills. I had heard great things about this course, and it was truly able to live up to those expectations.
Because communication is important, especially if we are trying to put forth ideas on environmental policy and solutions in this current poliltical and media climate.
I wanted to be a more effective and consistent communicator.
I had heard good things about it from other students, and it seemed universally applicable.
To improve my communication skills.
To improve my presentation, panel discussion, e-mail, elevator pitch, and powerpoint skills.
to become a better communicator
To communicate more effectively, to present/communicate more confidently, and to be a more engaging communicator.
Life skill, professional skill
These are fundamental skills.
I want to be an effective communicator.
to improve communication skills

Absolutely. I became aware of habits I hadn't realized I have.
Very much.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes

Yes. This is an excellent course.
Yes.
Yes.
Absolutely.
Yes.
yes
Yes, more than expected!
YES!
Yes, in fact even more useful than I expected.
I think so, but I realize that I need to work on these skills beyond what I could do within the class itself.
YES
yes

Yes!
Very much.
Yes.
Yes
More than I expected -- my presentation skills have noticeably improved.
Yes
Yes
Yes. And more.
Yes, although the nature of this course is very much dependent on experience. I think I will continue to improve these skills throughout my life.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I enjoyed the group work because it took some of the pressure off me as an individual and allowed us to measure up against our peers, and learn together.
Great to breakdown into smaller groups to practice presentations. Much less stressful than presenting in front of the entire class!

It was helpful to see other students present, but more often than not, students were quite under prepared. Therefore, the group practice sessions didn't show people "at their best" and therefore less student-to-student learning was achieved than could have been achieved.
The group project was useful, but I think it could be taken out and replaced with other tasks (I am not sure what exactly).
Nice to be put in front of audiences.However, some team members provided poor feedback at times.
Mostly advantages -- the break out sessions were small, comfortable environments to practice your public speaking.
N/A
Group work mostly involved getting feedback on your public speaking. It was very helpful since you got feedback not only from the instructor but from your peers as well.
The group work assigned was a good reflection of the kinds of activities one might experience in the professional world.
It helped give us a better idea of what it means to negotiate with others and work in a team.
Interesting to see how other students approach the same question.
we only had one group project and it was pretty well coordinated over e-mail in advance of the presentation.
group work was well facillitated and ran smoothly
Advantages were real-life simulation; disadvantages were the slowness and charade of a mock team meeting.
It was helpful to get peer feedback during presentations and in-class debates, etc. I didn't participate in any group work outside of the classroom.
the group assignment was theleast beneficial of the assignments.
Actual practice helps more than anything
Involving in group work is always a learning experience as well as a platform for sharing. I like working in group as it gives me opportunity to learn from them.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure you do the pre-work preparation thoroughly
Practice your presentations before you go to class. It'llhelp you get more out of the exercises.
Take it! Don't even think otherwise.It's one of the amazing assets to Yale and FES; you'd be foolish if you didn't take advantage of it!
Take it.
Don't prepare your pre-work for each class last minute. You will get more out of the class if you put some effort into preparing your speech, and treat it as a real presentation.
Participate in all activities and do the assignments.

You get out of this course what you put into it. With that said, I didn't put in tons of effort into my assignments because of time constraints but I still got a lot out of the course. Strongly recommend all FES students to take William's class.

I would advise taking the time to complete the out of class assignments and preparing speeches that are well rehearsed and practiced. The feedback you get is really helpful, so the closer your prepared material is to work you would produce in a real professional situation, the better you will benefit from the feedback.
Use it as a great opportunity to practice, so don't get nervous or take it too seriously.
Do the readings. It doesn't take long and they are informative and useful.
use the communication coaches.
You get out of it what you put in it.
Pay attention to the exercise, the more you practice, the more you take from the class.
More you put in, the more you get out.
do the homework and take it seriously
Just do it. It'snot the most fun way to spend 6 Monday evenings, but it's worth it.
You'll get more out of the class if you put a lot of time into the assignments, because then the feedback you get from your peers will be very valuable.
Take this course. Do the homework. Take notes.
Take it seriously, you can learn a lot
Come to class prepared.
take full advantage of the opportunity to get critical feedback from other students.
The course is very useful.
